conclusion: The image shows a p-V diagram for an ideal gas process
The gas goes from state A to state B to state C
At state C, the temperature is 300K
State A: approximately p = 3×10⁵ Pa, V = 5×10⁻³ m³
State B: approximately p = 2×10⁵ Pa, V = 6×10⁻³ m³
State C: approximately p = 5×10⁵ Pa, V = 2×10⁻³ m³
For an ideal gas, PV = nRT
P is pressure, V is volume, n is the number of moles, R is the gas constant, T is temperature
For a fixed amount of gas, we can write: (P1V1)/T1 = (P2V2)/T2
Find temperature at state B using state C as reference: TB = (PB × VB)/(PC × VC) × TC
Substitute the values from the graph: TB = (2 × 10^5 × 6 × 10^{-3})/(5 × 10^5 × 2 × 10^{-3}) × 300
The temperature of the gas in state B is 360 K
